headline: Biden’s Energy Balancing Act
abstract: The last few years have been great for energy production. You won’t hear the president bragging about it.
snippet: The last few years have been great for energy production. You won’t hear the president bragging about it.
lead_paragraph: A junior White House economist made a chart last year — the sort of chart that previous presidents might have put in a campaign ad. It shows that U.S. energy production, from wind and solar to oil and gas, has boomed under President Biden. The nation is closer than ever to a goal that presidents have pursued for decades: true energy independence.

headline: Why Are Influencers Pretending They Were Invited to an Oil Rig?
abstract: Several popular accounts on social media are pranking their loved ones by saying they’ve been invited to create offshore spon-con for Exxon Mobil.
snippet: Several popular accounts on social media are pranking their loved ones by saying they’ve been invited to create offshore spon-con for Exxon Mobil.
lead_paragraph: For certain social media influencers, brand-sponsored trips are just part of the job. If they’re lucky, they may find themselves admiring the Instagrammably blue waters of the Greek islands, or perhaps the pink sunsets of Bali. But what about endless ocean views from the metal decks of an offshore oil rig?

headline: Exxon Raises Questions About Chevron’s $53 Billion Deal for Hess
abstract: Exxon may try to upend its rival’s megadeal. The prize is a 30 percent stake in the oil-rich fields off the coast of Guyana.
snippet: Exxon may try to upend its rival’s megadeal. The prize is a 30 percent stake in the oil-rich fields off the coast of Guyana.
lead_paragraph: America’s two largest energy companies, Exxon Mobil and Chevron, are jousting over a prized new source of oil in the waters off Guyana, in Latin America.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Local Businesses?
abstract: Bookstores, pizza joints, Chinese restaurants, vintage shops, toy stores or anything else. What local spots do you want to celebrate?
snippet: Bookstores, pizza joints, Chinese restaurants, vintage shops, toy stores or anything else. What local spots do you want to celebrate?
lead_paragraph: Local, independent businesses are part of what makes a city or town unique, especially with the proliferation of chain stores and restaurants across the country and around the world.

headline: Biden to End an Unpopular Fuel Ban in Eight Farm States
abstract: The administration will scrap summertime restrictions on gas blended with ethanol, which is made from corn.
snippet: The administration will scrap summertime restrictions on gas blended with ethanol, which is made from corn.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration will permanently lift a ban on summertime sales of higher-ethanol gasoline blends in eight states starting in 2025, in response to a request from Midwestern governors who want year-round sales of the corn-based fuel.

headline: Why Oil Stocks Aren’t That Hot
abstract: We explore some of the patterns investors track to help understand what they show.
snippet: We explore some of the patterns investors track to help understand what they show.
lead_paragraph: Oil companies have recorded hundreds of billions of dollars in profits. Investment firms have backtracked their climate commitments. High interest rates are hurting clean energy companies.

headline: U.S. Campaign to Isolate Russia Shows Limits After 2 Years of War
abstract: Many nations insist on not taking sides in the war in Ukraine, while China, India and Brazil are filling Russia’s coffers.
snippet: Many nations insist on not taking sides in the war in Ukraine, while China, India and Brazil are filling Russia’s coffers.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration and European allies call President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia a tyrant and a war criminal. But he enjoys a standing invitation to the halls of power in Brazil.
byline: By Edward Wong and Michael Crowley

headline: Ban Fossil Fuels? Readers Had Strong Thoughts.
abstract: Some lauded the idea. Others said it would play into OPEC’s hands.
snippet: Some lauded the idea. Others said it would play into OPEC’s hands.
lead_paragraph: I got a lot of responses to my Friday newsletter on restricting the supply of fossil fuels, one of which said “oof no” in the subject line. It was from an economist named Benjamin Ho, who wrote that he usually likes my newsletter, “But, oh boy, was today’s off track.”

headline: Long Island and the Limits of Sabotage
abstract: Republicans’ deliberate chaos might not pay off.
snippet: Republicans’ deliberate chaos might not pay off.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Tom Suozzi won handily in the special election in New York’s Third Congressional District to fill the seat vacated by the serial fraudster George Santos — reclaiming the seat that Suozzi previously held. This was the latest in a series of Democratic victories in special elections, victories that seem on their face to run counter to polls showing Donald Trump leading Joe Biden in the presidential race.

headline: Virginia House Explosion Kills Firefighter and Injures 13 Others
abstract: Fire crews were responding to reports of a gas leak in Sterling, a suburb of Washington, when the home exploded with firefighters inside.
snippet: Fire crews were responding to reports of a gas leak in Sterling, a suburb of Washington, when the home exploded with firefighters inside.
lead_paragraph: A firefighter was killed after a house in Virginia exploded Friday night, injuring 13 other people and scattering pieces of the home across the neighborhood, officials said.
byline: By John Yoon and Aimee Ortiz

headline: Why Don’t We Just Ban Fossil Fuels?
abstract: The idea doesn’t make sense now, but it’s still worth thinking about.
snippet: The idea doesn’t make sense now, but it’s still worth thinking about.
lead_paragraph: Imagine there were no law against arson and we were trying to figure out a way to stop it. One way would be to require people to pay for the right to burn down buildings. Another would be to issue a strictly limited number of tradable arson-permission certificates, which would-be arsonists could trade among themselves. We could spend money making buildings more fireproof. Or we could invent new flammable objects that would satisfy arsonists’ desire to burn things down but whose combustion would cause less societal harm.

headline: Ross Gelbspan, Who Exposed Roots of Climate Change Deniers, Dies at 84
abstract: A longtime investigative journalist, he wrote books and articles that documented a campaign of disinformation intended to sow doubt about global warming.
snippet: A longtime investigative journalist, he wrote books and articles that documented a campaign of disinformation intended to sow doubt about global warming.
lead_paragraph: Ross Gelbspan, an investigative journalist whose reporting on climate change exposed a campaign of disinformation by oil and gas lobbyists to sow doubt about global warming — a denialism that was embraced by Republican officials and, in some cases, by a credulous news media — died on Jan. 27 at his home in Boston. He was 84.

headline: The $2.8 Billion Hole in U.S. Sanctions on Iran
abstract: A Times investigation reveals how lax government oversight allowed shadowy oil tankers, covered by American insurance, to fund Iran’s regime.
snippet: A Times investigation reveals how lax government oversight allowed shadowy oil tankers, covered by American insurance, to fund Iran’s regime.
lead_paragraph: A Times investigation reveals how lax government oversight allowed shadowy oil tankers, covered by American insurance, to fund Iran’s regime.
byline: By Christiaan Triebert, Blacki Migliozzi, Neil Bedi and Alexander Cardia

headline: Why This Group of Undecided Independent Voters Is Leaning Toward Trump
abstract: The participants discuss the issues that may sway them to vote for Biden or Trump.
snippet: The participants discuss the issues that may sway them to vote for Biden or Trump.
lead_paragraph: The participants discuss the issues that may sway them to vote for Biden or Trump.
byline: By Patrick Healy, Margie Omero and Adrian J. Rivera

headline: Two Big Texas Oil Producers Announce $26 Billion Merger
abstract: Diamondback Energy and Endeavor Energy Resources are both major players in the booming Permian Basin.
snippet: Diamondback Energy and Endeavor Energy Resources are both major players in the booming Permian Basin.
lead_paragraph: Two large Texas oil producers are joining forces in a deal valued at $26 billion, the latest in a wave of consolidation in the U.S. energy industry.

headline: How Two Irish Businessmen Almost Took Nigeria for $11 Billion
abstract: A mundane contractual provision met with rampant corruption — revealing a serious vulnerability in one of the backbones of international commerce.
snippet: A mundane contractual provision met with rampant corruption — revealing a serious vulnerability in one of the backbones of international commerce.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of explosive financial scandals, the story of Michael Quinn and Brendan Cahill could fairly be described as a simple proposition that spun completely out of control.

headline: How Ford’s F-150 Lightning, Once in Hot Demand, Lost Its Luster
abstract: Some buyers said the electric Lightning did not meet expectations, and Ford has slashed its production plans for the pickup because sales are lagging.
snippet: Some buyers said the electric Lightning did not meet expectations, and Ford has slashed its production plans for the pickup because sales are lagging.
lead_paragraph: In July Michael Puglia drove home with what seemed like the coolest vehicle he’d ever own — a Ford F-150 Lightning electric pickup truck.

headline: BP to Increase Oil Output, New Chief Says
abstract: Murray Auchincloss signaled that he would take a more profit-oriented approach than his predecessor, who started a big push into renewables.
snippet: Murray Auchincloss signaled that he would take a more profit-oriented approach than his predecessor, who started a big push into renewables.
lead_paragraph: BP’s new chief executive, Murray Auchincloss, promised a flexible approach to the shift away from fossil fuels as the oil giant reported a $3 billion profit in its latest quarter on Tuesday.

headline: Two Climate Advisers Quit U.S. Export-Import Bank Over Fossil Fuel Plans
abstract: The bank is set to vote Thursday on financing an oil project in Bahrain, the latest in a string of overseas fossil fuel projects.
snippet: The bank is set to vote Thursday on financing an oil project in Bahrain, the latest in a string of overseas fossil fuel projects.
lead_paragraph: A federal bank that finances projects overseas is set to vote on Thursday on whether to use taxpayer dollars to help drill oil and gas wells in Bahrain, a contentious decision that prompted two of the bank’s climate advisers to resign, according to people with knowledge of their decisions.
byline: By Lisa Friedman and Hiroko Tabuchi

headline: Why Are Americans Wary While the Economy Is Healthy? Look at Nevada.
abstract: Economic shocks over two decades, combined with reliance on volatile casinos, have undermined confidence despite an economy that’s bustling.
snippet: Economic shocks over two decades, combined with reliance on volatile casinos, have undermined confidence despite an economy that’s bustling.
lead_paragraph: Toni Irizarry recognizes that the economy has improved. Compared with the first wave of the pandemic, when Las Vegas went dark, and joblessness soared to levels not seen since the Great Depression, these are days of relative normalcy.
byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Bridget Bennett

headline: Bank of America Pledged to Stop Financing Coal. Now It’s Backtracking.
abstract: The changes come as Republican lawmakers step up efforts to punish businesses that consider climate change and the environment in their operations.
snippet: The changes come as Republican lawmakers step up efforts to punish businesses that consider climate change and the environment in their operations.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Bank of America won kudos from climate activists for saying it would no longer finance new coal mines, coal-burning power plants or Arctic drilling projects because of the toll they take on the environment.

headline: U.N. Climate Chief Warns Countries Against ‘Hiding Behind Loopholes’
abstract: Simon Stiell used a speech in Azerbaijan to set expectations for global climate negotiations there this year.
snippet: Simon Stiell used a speech in Azerbaijan to set expectations for global climate negotiations there this year.
lead_paragraph: In a speech on Friday, the United Nations climate chief painted an optimistic picture of the fight against global warming while taking a jab at countries that avoid meeting their obligations by “hiding behind loopholes” in global agreements.

headline: The Economy Looks Sunny, a Potential Gain for Biden
abstract: Recession fears have eased. Growth and job gains are beating expectations. Inflation is cooling. Consumers are happier. The president is waiting to benefit.
snippet: Recession fears have eased. Growth and job gains are beating expectations. Inflation is cooling. Consumers are happier. The president is waiting to benefit.
lead_paragraph: A run of strong economic data appears to have finally punctured consumers’ sour mood about the U.S. economy, blasting away recession fears and potentially aiding President Biden in his re-election campaign.

headline: Oil Giants Pump Their Way to Bumper Profits
abstract: Exxon, Chevron and Shell reported robust earnings and large payouts to investors as they continued to expand their fossil-fuel production.
snippet: Exxon, Chevron and Shell reported robust earnings and large payouts to investors as they continued to expand their fossil-fuel production.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the largest U.S. energy companies, on Friday reported sizable profits for the final quarter of last year, showing that the oil and gas industry remained robust at a time of doubts because of climate change concerns.

headline: They Love Costco So Much They Wrote a Book About It
abstract: David and Susan Schwartz, who live in a tiny Manhattan apartment, have visited more than 200 Costco stores.
snippet: David and Susan Schwartz, who live in a tiny Manhattan apartment, have visited more than 200 Costco stores.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll meet a Manhattan couple who went to 47 states and 14 countries for a book about Costco. We’ll also find out about a four-decade fight to exonerate two men convicted of killing a French tourist in a mugging in 1987.
